video.title: Six Quick Python Projects
video.description:
Improve your Python programming skills by coding six different Python projects. You will create a web scraping program, a bulk file renamer, a weather program, a countdown timer, a password generator, and a QR code encoder / decoder.

✏️ Course developed by Code With Tomi. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/CodeWithTomi

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
(00:00) Intro
(00:37) Web Scraping Program
(13:53) Renaming Bulk Files
(24:54) Getting Weather Information
(33:12) Countdown Timer
(42:11) Password Generator
(53:12) QR Code With Python

Connect With Tomi:
🐦 Twitter: https://twitter.com/TomiTokko3
📄 Newsletter: https://www.codewithtomi.ml/p/newsletter.html (and get a python ebook for free)

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

replies.author: hexidecimalAFF0
replies.text: Like you, I was initially confused. Then I realized it's in Kelvins (K, absolute temp). So when I used a Kelvins(K) to Celsius(C) or, Kelvins(K) to Fahrenheit(F) conversion, the values made much more everyday sense.

topLevelComment.author: William Ovares
topLevelComment.text: Hello, I have a question. Why did you add this value after the first "for loop", passwords= " "? Why is the option after = blank? Thank you!

replies.author: Vanessa Y
replies.text: Because in the loop you see " passwords += random.choice(chars) ", which means you add a random character to an already EXISTING, defined variable. If you do not state the variable before this line, it cannot add a character to the variable, because the variable is not defined. You will get an error code. Therefore we have to define the variable "password" before we add characters, but we do not want any characters at the start, so we use blank. Hope this helps! Sorry if my explanation is messy, English is my second language :)

topLevelComment.author: nowon kjhg
topLevelComment.text:
My timer doesn't show up when I run the program. I input the amount of time, it waits that long, then prints "timer completed". The whole "00:00" doesn't appear. However, when I remove the ", end="\r" " from the program, the timer appears, but it prints a new timer after every second. Like this:
00:03
00:02
00:01
My code is exactly like yours so why is this happening?

replies.author: Vanessa Y
replies.text: Same here too! I solved it by changing it to this: print(f"\r{timer}", end = "") This way there is no newline printed after the end, and in the next loop at the start the cursor goes back to the beginning of the line. Hope it helps! I still don't get why the original doesn't work for us... :/

replies.author: SchwedenMein Heimatland
replies.text: It is based entirely on your own predisposition for learning and what you want to do with your coding, I would say. It's most certainly not too late to pick up a new skill such as coding, and a very useful one at that. I started programming at a young age and I attend university pursuing a degree in Computer Science. I have had multiple lab partners who have had no experience at all in coding when we all started the education, but they are just as good as me now, if not better. So I don't think it's all too important to start early with coding, if you like what you are doing you may even find yourself surpassing people that did start early, as my friends have done with me, surpassed me that is. All the best and regards from Sweden.

replies.author: Fabian
replies.text:
Just had the same problem when trying on instagram, and I think the reason why it doesn't work is because you (aka the program in this case) needs to be logged in to access the page. You can see this if you try to access the URL in incognito mode, which will prompt you with a login page.

I don't really know if it's possible to make the program login for you but another way to get data from instagram is to use an API, either instagram's own or other 3rd party APIs

topLevelComment.author: Patryk Kotarski
topLevelComment.text:
Project 1: that's not a real use of webscraping. Github offers APIs to receive such information with much less effort
Project 2: You're removing spaces after an equal sign... that's a sign of a very beginner developer
Project 3: Ok
Project 4: The countdown timer will stop working if your pc under heavy cpu load as time.sleep() will not compute in exactly 1 second, this will never happen and this is not a good way to ensure that the timer stays always correct
Project 5: You better fucking *not* try to teach people how to password generate. You're not able to. It's a very complex topic and passwords that *look* secure to you actually aren't. Systems have been hacked in the past where the password was generated in a similar way. *PLEASE* don't use this method of generating your passwords
Project 6: Ok

Overall, very beginner experience that doesn't know how to create a real project. These are simply snippets of test code to prove a point that you can usually find on the github pages of the related library.
He doesn't teach anything that another beginner doesn't already know, since he himself is a beginner.
He doesn't seem to have any professional experience on real projects or any idea how to debug a program.

I'm not criticising him as a developer or as a person, I find it *very* wrong that you post videos of beginners creating not just confusion but *harm* to other people (see the password generation project)

I hope not to see more projects like this in the future

replies.author: nowon kjhg
replies.text: These projects are meant to teach basic python stuff dude chill out. Nobody is watching these with the intention of creating a marketable product. This is just teaching you how to use stuff like "time" and "random".

replies.author: Patryk Kotarski
replies.text: @Ivan Yosifov right but that doesn’t fall under the definition of “project” and the overall channel objective

replies.author: Ivan Yosifov
replies.text: The point of these projects is not to teach production level code, rather to show how to do simple stuff in Python. Beginners should start from somewhere.
